instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.LCDBKLT_FB: What is LCDBKLT_FB? LCDBKLT_FB is a feedback line between backlight output and the feedback pin on the LED driver. When this connection is broken, backlight output will be equal to PPBUS_G3H voltage of the system rather than boosting. Since this point is the highest voltage in the system, it is the fastest to corrode when liquid damaged, so it is a very common point to check when there is no backlight. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Yes I'm pretty new at this. No I haven't found an article for this specific issue:)

I tried this first with the board out and no LCD connected.. I assume this is the wrong way to test circuits so I connected the LCD panel.

Here is what I found and can you please assist me in sorting this out? one odd thing I found is that as I tested some pins on some Resistors etc. The voltage was slowly decreasing.

Thank you in advance,
Chris

<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> pin 17 en  3.3v
F7700 12.58v

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0W_LCDBKLT_R</SIGNAL>  pin 1 <CAPACITOR>C7700</CAPACITOR> 12.58V  pin 2 12.78V
<RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR> pin 1 12.59v  Pin 2 12.48V

<TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>
Pin 1  10.2v and decreasing
Pin2  8.36 and decreasing
Pin3  12.49v
Pin4  12.59v
Pin5  7.62 decreasing
Pin67.02 decreasing

L7710 PIN 1 8.2V and decreasing  PIN 2 8.1V Decreasing

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
J8300 Pin 1 12.5V

threads.message: Voltage on Pin 30??? If you use a flashlight , can you see any image???? have you tried whit a known good display assembly??

Yes the LCD is good. Can see the Apple Logo etc. HDMI port works also.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I had the original LCD and had a an image but no backlight.  Now, With the board out of the case but plugged into the LCD I cant even see an image..
Pin 30 has 5.1V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I put the board back into the case and I have a no backlight scenario. There is video, just no backlight. with 5.1V at pin 30

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: With 5V on pin 30 there should be something on the LCD. What voltage is on pin 1? Only 2015 LCD assemblies will work on these boards, make sure you have the correct one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: This is the original one for this MBP  Pin 1 has 12.54V.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
So it is not boosting. Was this liquid damage? 
Voltage on <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR>, with LCD connected.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Yes, liquid damage. Bad keyboard also.(not connected) 3.3v on <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> with the lcd connected

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Corrosion in <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> area? Check feedback circuit <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>/32
Where was corrosion?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
no obvious corrosion. I see a very little bit at these 3 resistors
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> 12.5v on pin 1  nothing on pin 2..   no voltage on either side of <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR>..  
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>  Nothing..
<RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> 150k Ohms

Looks like <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> is bad

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
What a pain no 13.3k resistors  on any of my bad boards
...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: So I finally found a 13.7 not the 13.3..... will this work?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: That's only a 3% difference; if it's the same package, and will fit without issues, it should be fine as long as the original spec tolerance is 5%.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Tolerance is 1% on these

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Yeah, then it won't work. Find one in-spec is your best bet.

ill just keep searching. Thank you for your help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Finally!  Cheese and Rice.. This was a real pain.. As it tuned out, there was a test point Tp[1]<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL> had what looked like very minor corrosion, almost not visible..  I couldn't get continuity between <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> and the test point 2 millimeters to the left of the Resistor..  This goes directly to Pin 21 on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>...

I soldered a wire in place and wahlah (badabing in NYC area) I have video..

Thank you for the help and patience..  :)
